title: Quiz 6: Endocrine & Reproductive Systems
description: Final assessment covering hormones (Insulin, Corticosteroids, Thyroid), Diuretics, and Reproductive health agents (Contraceptives, Labor drugs) (Unit 16).

questions.question: Match the specific drug to its therapeutic classification:
questions.explanation: Metformin treats diabetes; Levothyroxine treats hypothyroidism; Furosemide treats edema; Oxytocin stimulates labor.
questions.hint: Match the drug to the organ system it affects (Pancreas, Thyroid, Kidney, Uterus).

questions.question: Which of the following are symptoms of Hypoglycemia (Insulin Reaction)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Hypoglycemia causes sympathetic surges: sweating, tremors, hunger, and pallor. Hot/dry skin and fruity breath are signs of Hyperglycemia (DKA).
questions.hint: Think: 'Cold and clammy, need some candy.'

questions.question: Which is the ONLY type of Insulin that may be administered Intravenously (IV)?
questions.explanation: Regular insulin is the only preparation safe for IV administration. All suspensions (NPH, Lente) are for SC use only.
questions.hint: It is the clear one.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for the treatment of Diabetic Coma as described in the study material:

items.text: Administer 20 units of insulin every 30 minutes
Give Dextrose (1g per unit of insulin) to avoid hypoglycemia
Monitor vital signs and urine samples

questions.explanation: Initial bolus -> Maintenance dosing -> Glucose cover to prevent crash -> Monitoring.
questions.hint: Start with the loading dose.

questions.question: Review the 'ACHES' Acronym Table for Oral Contraceptives. What does the 'A' represent?

richContent.content:
LetterWarning Sign
A???
CChest pain
HHeadache (severe)
EEye problems
SSevere leg pain

questions.explanation: A = Abdominal pain (severe), which may indicate liver or gallbladder problems.
questions.hint: Pain in the stomach area.

questions.question: Corticosteroids should be discontinued abruptly after long-term therapy to prevent side effects.
questions.explanation: False. Steroids must be tapered slowly. Abrupt withdrawal can cause adrenal insufficiency (Addisonian crisis), anorexia, nausea, and hypotension.
questions.hint: Think about the adrenal glands needing time to 'wake up'.

questions.question: Which of the following are side effects associated with long-term Adrenocorticosteroid (Steroid) therapy? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Steroids cause Cushing-like symptoms (moon face), catabolism (osteoporosis), immunosuppression, and HYPERglycemia (not hypo).
questions.hint: Think Cushing's Syndrome symptoms.

questions.question: Which immune globulin is administered to Rh-negative women exposed to Rh-positive blood (e.g., after delivery) to prevent antibody formation?
questions.explanation: RhoGAM (Rho(D) Immune Globulin) prevents the production of anti-Rh(D) antibodies in Rh-negative mothers.
questions.hint: Brand name starts with 'R'.

questions.question: What is the specific action of Furosemide (Lasix)?

options.text: It inhibits sodium reabsorption in the ascending loop of Henle.
It blocks aldosterone receptors in the distal tubule.
It acts as an osmotic diuretic.

questions.explanation: Furosemide is a 'Loop' diuretic because it acts on the ascending loop of Henle to inhibit Na/Cl reabsorption.
questions.hint: It is classified as a Loop Diuretic.

questions.question: When administering Oxytocin (Pitocin) for labor induction, it should never be given as an undiluted intravenous ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: Oxytocin must be diluted and given via infusion pump. Giving it as a bolus can cause uterine rupture and fetal distress.
questions.hint: A rapid injection.

questions.question: Which medication is contraindicated for labor induction because it may cause uterine tetany and rupture, but is used for postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.explanation: Methergine produces sustained uterine contractions (tetany). This is useful for stopping bleeding postpartum but dangerous for a fetus during labor.
questions.hint: Used AFTER the baby is born.

questions.question: Metformin (Glucophage) works by stimulating the pancreas to secrete more insulin.
questions.explanation: False. Metformin improves insulin sensitivity and decreases liver glucose production. Sulfonylureas (like Glyburide) stimulate pancreatic secretion.
questions.hint: Metformin does not cause hypoglycemia as easily because of this mechanism.

questions.question: Which electrolyte imbalance is a major side effect of Furosemide (Lasix) therapy?
questions.explanation: Furosemide causes the excretion of Potassium along with Sodium and water, leading to Hypokalemia.
questions.hint: Patients often need to eat bananas or take supplements.

questions.question: What is the term for the 'hyperglycemic rebound' effect that occurs in patients who receive chronic insulin overdoses?
questions.explanation: The Somogyi effect is rebound hyperglycemia following an episode of hypoglycemia (often at night).
questions.hint: Starts with 'S'.

questions.question: Which of the following drugs are used to treat Hyperthyroidism (Antithyroid drugs)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: PTU and Methimazole inhibit thyroid hormone production. Levothyroxine and Liothyronine are thyroid hormone replacements.
questions.hint: Drugs that stop the thyroid vs. drugs that replace hormones.

questions.question: A patient is prescribed Terbutaline Sulfate (Bricanyl). Besides being a bronchodilator, what is its other indication in obstetrics?
questions.explanation: Terbutaline relaxes smooth muscle (beta-2 agonist), making it effective for bronchodilation AND stopping uterine contractions (tocolysis) in preterm labor.
questions.hint: It relaxes the uterus.

questions.question: When instructing a patient on oral contraceptives, the nurse should advise using the ACHES acronym. The 'C' stands for ___BLANK___ pain or shortness of breath.
questions.explanation: C = Chest pain, which could indicate a pulmonary embolism or heart attack (complications of clots).
questions.hint: Location of the heart and lungs.

questions.question: Which drug acts by reducing gastric acid secretion and increasing gastric mucus, but also induces uterine contractions (used in Cytotec)?
questions.explanation: Misoprostol is an anti-ulcer agent (prostaglandin analog) that also causes uterine contractions and is contraindicated in pregnancy (unless used for induction/abortion).
questions.hint: Often used to prevent ulcers from NSAIDs.

questions.question: Match the Insulin Type with its classification:
questions.explanation: Regular is rapid; NPH/Lente are intermediate; PZI/Ultralente are long-acting.
questions.hint: Regular is fast.

questions.question: Why is it recommended to discontinue oral Furosemide (Lasix) 1 week before surgery?

options.text: It potentiates the effects of muscle relaxants.

questions.explanation: Furosemide can potentiate the action of muscle relaxants used during anesthesia/surgery, so it is often held beforehand.
questions.hint: Interaction with anesthesia drugs.
